description: No one has returned Oscar Teevan's dog as of yet.

Mrs. Nance invites us in her sitting room. We notice a wicker basket, and a blanket in a corner of the room, close to the front door. "Did you find Charly?". She slumps in an armchair, fixing then a picture of her dog, carrying a ball in his mouth. "This is my only souvenir of him now", she states sadly. I haven't been able to lay my hands on his favourite ball for a week, and now he's the one who disappeared...". Also I don't feel very safe - he let me know when anybody was nearby, he would bark incessantly when people approached.

"And did your nephew find anything?"

"Howie? No but I think his mind is on other things. He comes to see me every Thursday, but last Thursday he got here very late and was restless. He didn't want to tell me what was bothering him. Do you think he's in some kind of trouble?" she asks us concerned.

The manager of Grosvenor Investments receives us but does not tell us anything that we have not read in the Times article. He is sorry for Mrs. Nance's dog, but he has other things to take care of.

After a few contortions, we find a way to discreetly enter in the premises located under the attic, but we are soon stopped by a man. "Hey guys, what do you think you're doing?". "We're investigating...". "You see, after what happened last night, I'm not in a talkative mood.. John tell the night watchman that we found the passage the other snoopers took to get in. And you, out!"

Mrs. Nance invites us in her sitting room. We notice a wicker basket, and a blanket in a corner of the room, close to the front door. "Did you find Charly?". She slumps in an armchair, fixing then a picture of her dog, carrying a ball in his mouth. "This is my only souvenir of him now", she states sadly. I haven't been able to lay my hands on his favourite ball for a week, and now he's the one who disappeared...". Also I don't feel very safe - he let me know when anybody was nearby, he would bark incessantly when people approached.

"And did your nephew find anything?"

"Howie? No but I think his mind is on other things. He comes to see me every Thursday, but last Thursday he got here very late and was restless. He didn't want to tell me what was bothering him. Do you think he's in some kind of trouble?" she asks us concerned.

location: 34NW - Gloria Stern, Yvonne's neighbor and friend
description:
Gloria Stern, an upright middle aged woman with a brisk demeanor, invites us in for tea and cakes. We sit down and ask her if she knows anything about the dog or Yvonne's situation.

"About the dog going missing? No. But I do know that dog doesn't let anybody anywhere near Yvonne's residence without raising the biggest fuss. I can almost work out the full schedule of Yvonne and the goings about around her house solely based on his yapping. The only thing that quiets that damn dog is food or his favorite ball".

"What about Yvonne Nance herself?"

"Oh Yvonne is nice enough but I wouldn't trust her with any secret! I'm serious, she leaks like a sieve. Any time she hears the smallest tidbit of information, she makes sure to let me know - and even when she means to keep news secret, she can't help herself! Boy has this news of her dog disappearance traveled fast - I bet that people in the next town have already heard it by now!"

"Ok, anything else?"

"nothing.. but please find that damn dog. Yvonne is so worried, and if you find him, I can get some rest after she stops telling me about it."

The young florist is not insensitive to Wiggins' charm and helps us gladly. "If you're talking about the enigmatic gentleman, he told me he had to buy violets to be forgiven for his mischieviousness".
The meat dealer looks at us: 'You don't look like you wanna buy anything so shoo!'
One of the contortionists remembers seeing on Tuesday a rushing young man, followed by a German Spitz. The dog seemed to be in a playful mood, hopping around the man holding something is his hand.
The waiter does not seem to understand our questions. Yes, yes, dog very good! A little too much noisy! Very nice lady.

A red face man welcomes us into his butcher shop. He prepares before us a terrine, meticulously grinding a game's meat, whose origin we can hardly identify. "Ah! You are here for the old bag's pooch? Saw nothing, heard nothing but I won't complain. I thought I was coming to a quiet neighborhood, and not a night went without the dog barking at every passer by. It was hell! I tolerated it beecause the lady came to take her regular lot of kidneys for her 'precious'. Not easy to sell them, and only on a per order basis. He was probably better pampered than Queen Victoria's dog himself. The world is crazy trust me.

As we search the bushes, we see in the mud the traces of the dog's paws joined seemingly by those of a man, and leaving in the same direction, due east. We find an abandoned string a little farther on.

Mycroft receives us in the visitors sitting room of the Diogenes Club. Oppenheimer was already politically compromised, but this recent affair may very well put an end to his career. If proofs are the slightest bit credible. And we are talking about the times, not a vulgar rag.
Lestrade threatens to kick us out by force when we tell him the reason for our visit.
There is no one in the Parliament who wants to comment on the Oppenheimer affair.

We review th Somerset House logbooks: Yvonne Nance, nee Parker. Married  to Robert Nance on August 17, 1857 (Robert Nance, deceased on December 13, 1885); no child, only one brother him too deceased, no will on record.
Patric Hennesy does not know Mrs. Nance and does not understand one word of our questions, nor why we came to see him.
"No comment on the case" is the sole response we obtain at the parliamentarian's home.

The owner of the Raven and Rat, Porky Shinwell, seems amused by our questions. "So now you're reduced to looking for a pooch? I hope he didn't bite a bad guy because in such a case, a good bag and off to the bottom of the Thames!"

We follow Cannon street up to number 68 and knock on the door of Howard Parker's flat, on the third floor. A young man, looking sleepy, receives us in the corridor, shutting the door behind him. A tad surprised by our investigation, he quickly shortens the conversation. "For the time being, I haven't heard anything about Charly, but I'm not particularly worried. Every dog hashis day! My aunt worries way to much and I've better things to do. And so do you, don't you?"
When we ask him, if by chance he received unusual orders recently, the butcher of cannon street answers that a new client specifically requested offal last week and was to pick them up on Tuesday.
